sense.name: physically hit, strike, or propel with foot
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] KICK NP2[patient] (PP{P NP[location]})
sense.examples: I kicked the ball as hard as I could. He was accused of kicking a man in the face. She felt the baby kicking inside her. Looks like you kicked down the door and took your best shot! They kicked the ball downstairs. They kicked the ball upstairs. They kicked the ball back into the box. They kicked the ball around. They kicked the ball about the house.

sense.name: be alive or be active; wander or wait
sense.commentary: Includes: KICK ABOUT, KICK AROUND, KICK ONE'S HEELS
sense.examples: Is he still kicking around the house with a job? He still kicks about town. Does the old man still kick around. She kicked her heels for hours at the game of the embassy.

sense.name: KICK AROUND-discuss or consider
sense.examples: We kicked the notion around with the gentleman ambassador. You can kick the idea around on your own time table and succeed or fail.

sense.name: KICK AROUND-abuse or treat harshly
sense.examples: Those bullies kicked him around a bit, didn't they? I won't let them kick me around anymore!

sense.name: KICK OUT-expel or remove from position
sense.examples: They kicked us out of the mall for sliding down the bannisters. We are Denver residents who were kicked out of the President's Town Hall Conversation. He got kicked out for laughing at the teacher. They kicked the chairman out for misappropriating funds.

sense.name: KICK IN-set in or become active
sense.examples: Right now, I'm waiting for the effects of the medication to kick in. Now the reason you finally realized it was simply that your anger kicked in. With the new coverage that kicked in last month, we'll be able to afford it.

sense.name: KICK IN-chip in something; contribute
sense.examples: Mom and dad kicked a few dollars in to help me buy my car. The government kicked in some $30000 to cover the costs of shipping the pellets.

sense.name: KICK UP-raise or increase
sense.examples: I'll teach you how to kick it up a notch! Thankfully, the new installation kicked the heat up a bit. The haunting aromatics of cumin and curry kicked it up to a ringing High C.

sense.name: KICK OFF-start or commence; take off
sense.examples: The Braves kicked the season off right, scoring in only the game's first 36 seconds. We kicked the year off making modifications to our new home in Victoria St. I officially kicked off the party with a short welcoming speech.

sense.name: KICK BACK-relax
sense.examples: When do you find time to kick back and read? Kick back and relax!

sense.name: KICK BACK-spring back or recoil from a thrust
sense.examples: I fired and the gun kicked back and knocked my mask off.

sense.name: KICK BACK-make illegal payment
sense.examples: Both men are accused of kicking back lump sums to the criminal.

sense.name: KICK DOWNSTAIRS-reduce in rank or position; demote
sense.examples: So the solutions for national problems get kicked downstairs. They kicked him downstairs for using the company resources for his own good.

sense.name: KICK UPSTAIRS-increase in rank or position; promote
sense.examples: Under the new management, our petition was kicked upstairs. We kicked him upstairs to a cushy job as Chairmain of our new division.

sense.name: stop or quit an activity or habit
sense.examples: To kick my habit, I sought out some of the stranger places to drink in this town.

sense.name: complain
sense.examples: She has a lot to kick about. Stop kicking about your old sixth hole! You've had the darndest luck I ever saw, and yet you grumble.

sense.name: KICK THE BUCKET-die
sense.examples: If you say someone kicked the bucket, you mean someone died.
